result.heading: A SIKH SOLDIER RUNNING ACROSS THE FIELD WAVING HIS ARMS,
VIA THE HOLE RIPPED OUT OF THE WALL

direction.raw_text: .    DAY. Hana plays.  GUN SHOTS punctuates the music.  She's totally engrossed and only hears the second or third shot.  Her hands falter, she looks up to see A SIKH SOLDIER RUNNING ACROSS THE FIELD WAVING HIS ARMS, his REVOLVER held aloft.  He approaches the door, his face creased with anxiety, and raps on the shattered frame.  It's KIP. She gets up and walks past Kip standing at the door, and continues the seven or eight feet to the right and out into the garden VIA THE HOLE RIPPED OUT OF THE WALL.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me.  Yes? (of the doors) I don't have the key to that door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Germans were here.  The Germans were all over this area.  They left mines everywhere.  Pianos were their favorite hiding places. HANA I see. (then mischievous) Then may be you're safe as long as you only play Bach.  He's German. Kip is looking around the piano.  Hana giggles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is something funny?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, but, no, not at all.  I'm sorry. You came to the doors, that's all and - (a little laugh) #NAME? worried about mines.  That's all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've met you before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think so. Hana bends to see what Kip's looking at under the piano.  Wires run from the wall to the instrument onto which is taped an EXPLOSIVE CHARGE.   If Hana had succeeded in moving the piano she would have triggered the charge.  Kip looks at Hana who conceals her dismay with a shrug. 110a*.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: HARDY AND KIP ARE PUTTING UP THEIR TENTS

direction.raw_text: .    DUSK. Across from the terrace, HARDY AND KIP ARE PUTTING UP THEIR TENTS. Caravaggio stands, chatting amiably to them, holding a haversack, smoking a cigarette. 111*.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    DUSK. Hana looks down from the Patient's room, watching the tents go up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wants us to move out, says there could be fifty more mines in the building. He thinks I'm mad because I laughed at him.  He's Indian, he wears a turban.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sikh.  If he wears a turban, he's a Sikh. Kip glances up at the window.  Hana, suddenly shy, backs away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll probably marry him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really?  That's sudden.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My mother always told me I would summon my husband by playing the piano. She goes over to the Patient's bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I liked it better when there were just the two of us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?  Is he staying?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With his Sergeant.  A Mr. Hardy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We should charge!  Doesn't anyone have a job to do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They have to clear all the local roads of mines.  That's a big job.  They won't stay in the house.  They're putting up their tent in the garden.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In that case, I suppose we can't charge. 112*.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    CAIRO.    DAY. A SMALL OFFICE, shared by two men, and a mountain of filing cabinets and paper.  There are AERIAL MAPS all over the walls.  Clifton is on the telephone, while his colleague, RUPERT DOUGLAS, works at the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darling, it's me, I'm sorry, something's come up. (Katharine responds) Don't sulk - I'll be back tomorrow evening.  I promise. (Katharine responds) Okay my precious, I love you. Rupert makes a face at his friend's sentimentality.  Clifton beams.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't know you were going anywhere?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not.  I'm going to surprise her. It's our anniversary.  She's forgotten, of course.  What's the symbol for your first anniversary?  I should get something. Is it paper? (he knocks sharply on the wall) Moose!  Moose, you there?  First Anniversary - is it cotton?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is what cotton?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: First Wedding Anniversary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's hopeless!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your day will come, my sausage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your first anniversary is Paper. 113
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   O/S  SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL.    DAY. The approach to the Shepheard's Hotel.  Geoffrey Clifton in a TAXI, champagne between his knees. The car ahead of them SCREECHES TO A HALT as a WOMAN hurries across the street.  The driver honks his horn angrily.  The woman puts up a hand in apology as she skips across the street to another taxi.  IT'S KATHARINE - she's dressed for a date, carries flowers, an overnight bag. Geoffrey, at first excited, is troubled by the accouterments.  Then he sees Katharine skip and his whole being punctures. Katharine's cab roars off.  His own car jerks forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yessir. Geoffrey sits in the cab.  Fifty yards short of the hotel.  The world rushes by.  He finds a cigarette. 114
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    LATE DAY. Katharine is in bed.  Almasy has just put A RECORD on.  It's the folk song heard at the beginning of the film.  He slips back under the covers.  Their clothes are scattered around the room.  He lies over a happy Katharine.  She listens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is - what is this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a folk song.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arabic?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no, it's Hungarian.  My daijka sang it to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's beautiful.  What's it about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a long song - Szerelem means love...and the story - there's a Hungarian Count, he's a wanderer, a fool.  For years he's on some kind of quest, who knows what?  And then one day he falls under the spell of a mysterious English woman - a harpy - who beats him and hits him and he becomes her slave.  He sews her clothes, he worships the hem of - Katharine had thought for a few seconds he was serious, then she catches on and starts to beat him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ouch!  See - you're always beating me..!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You bastard, I was believing you! They embrace, he lies over her, considering her naked back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I claim this shoulder blade - oh no, wait - I want this! He turns her over, kisses her throat, then traces the hollow indentation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This - what's it called? - this place, I love it - this is mine! (Katharine doesn't know) I'm asking the King permission to call it the Almasy Bosphorous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought we were against ownership? (kissing him) I can stay tonight. The luxury of this makes them both sad.  The duplicity.  Almasy rolls away on to his back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Madox knows, I think.  He's tried to warn me.  He keeps talking about Anna Karenina.  I think it's his idea of a man-to-man chat.  Its my idea of a man-to-man chat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is a different world - is what I tell myself.  A different life. And here I am a different wife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.  A different wife. 115
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .  CAIRO STREET.  O/S SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL.  NIGHT. The CAB DRIVER is asleep. A loud POP! jerks him awake.  In the back of the car Geoffrey has opened the champagne.  He lets it overflow, then takes a swig.  He notices the startled driver and puts up an apologetic arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry. Two or three CHILDREN knock on the window, begging.  Geoffrey knocks back, violently.  They disappear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hotel now, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. And he throws a silencing wad of money onto the seat by the Cabbie. 116
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    OLD CAIRO.    DAWN. Almasy and Katharine wander out of his building and into the early morning streets, hand in hand. 117
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    CAIRO.    DAWN. The MORNING PRAYERS rise out from the city's three Minarets.  Almasy stops at a stall, which is just preparing to open for the day.  He picks up a SILVER THIMBLE, points at it to the merchant who gives him a price.  Without comment, Almasy produces the money and, beaming, hands the thimble to Katharine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't care to bargain. (she smiles) It's full of saffron, just in case you think I'm giving it to you to encourage your sewing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That day, had you followed me to the market?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course.  You didn't need to slap my face to make me feel as if you'd slapped my face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shall we be all right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.  Yes. (shrugs) Absolutely. 118
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    DAWN. Katharine takes leave of Almasy on the street corner away from the hotel entrance.  They don't kiss, there's no demonstration of feeling. He turns immediately away and disappears. 119
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .  CAIRO STREET.  O/S SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL.  DAY. Geoffrey, unshaven, watches as Katharine crosses the street and heads towards the hotel.  His expression is terrible, trying to smile, his face collapsed. 120
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    MORNING. Cheek to Cheek leaks into the room from a GRAMOPHONE that Caravaggio stands over proudly.  The Patient opens his eyes - is confused, dislocated - stares blankly at Caravaggio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thought you'd never wake up!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? Hana comes in, sleepily, frowns at the gramophone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where did you find that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I liberated it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think that's called looting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No-one should own music.  The real question is who wrote the song?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Irving Berlin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Top Hat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is there a song you don't know?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  He sings all the time. She goes over to the Patient and kisses him gently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning. (of his singing) Did you know that?  You're always singing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been told that before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kip's another one. She goes to the window, looks over to where the tents are pitched, sees Hardy shaving, Kip IN THE PROCESS OF WASHING HIS HAIR, his turban HANGING LIKE A RIBBON between two trees to dry.  He's perched a bowl on the sundial and is dipping his long coal-black hair into it.  As Hana watches Kip, Caravaggio changes the record.  The Patient identifies it immediately. 121*.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: IN THE PROCESS OF WASHING HIS HAIR,

direction.raw_text: .     MORNING. Hana walks past the tent, and passes Hardy.  She's carrying a small cup, which she's a little furtive about.  He's carrying a whole armada of OIL LIGHTS.  He nods upstairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello miss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was going to say - if you want to eat with us, ever... you and Lieutenant Singh...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very kind of you, we can always eat in the town with the others -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Since Caravaggio turned up - food seems to appear, so please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll ask the Lieutenant.  But thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You saved my life.  I haven't forgotten. (Hardy waves that away) I thought you were very very tall.  You seemed to big - a Giant - and I felt like a child who can't keep her balance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A toddler She goes on, and tentatively approaches Kip, who's still working at his hair.  Kip hears her and puts out an inquiring arm, moving towards her like a blink man through the curtain of hair.  He touches her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry, is it all right I'm seeing this? Kip shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My hair was long.  At some point. I've forgotten what a nuisance it is to wash.  You know - if you were ever around - we get water from the pump at noon. He continues to wash.  She holds up the cup of oil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Try this.  I found a great jar of it. Olive oil.  In Naples this was so precious it would have bought you a wife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. She stands for a second, then walks away.  Kip examines the oil, calls after her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For my hair?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, for your hair. 122
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    HANA'S GARDEN.    DAY. HANA IS GARDENING, close to the crucifix, which is now a full-fledged Scarecrow.  Broken bottles, fragments of stained glass and shards from a mirror are hung from the crossbar, syringes too, all jangling and tinkling and catching the sunlight. Kip and Hardy drive off to work on their motorcycles.  She watches them, catching Kip's careless wave to her.  She looks briefly at herself in A PIECE OF MIRROR dangling from the Scarecrow. 123
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    UPSTAIRS LANDING.    DAY. Hana walks along the landing with a tray.  There's a message on several doors in the corridor from Kip: SAFE, then a couple with the warning: DANGER.  She hears noise from the Patient's room.  Listens for a second before going in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because you're reading it too fast!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not at all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have to read Kipling slowly! Your eye is too impatient - think about the speed of his pen. (quoting Kipling to demonstrate) What is it - He sat comma in defiance of municipal orders comma astride the gun Zamzammah on her brick... What is it? 124
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    DAY. During this, Hana comes through with the tray, finds Kip perched on the window, relishing his skirmish with the Patient, who has condensed milk dribbling down his neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brick platform opposite the old Ajaib-Gher -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: #NAME? natives called the Lahore Museum.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's still there, the cannon, outside the museum.  It was made of metal cups and bowls taken from every household in the city as tax, then melted down. Then later they fired the cannon at my people - comma - The natives.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what do you really object to - the writer or what he's writing about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What I really object to, Uncle, is your finishing all my condensed milk. (snatching up the empty can) And the message everywhere in your book - however slowly I read it - that the best destiny for India is to be ruled by the British.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hana, we have discovered a shared please - the boy and I.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arguing about books.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Condensed milk - one of the truly great inventions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll get another tin. Hana and the Patient are alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't like that book either.  It's all about men.  Too many men. Just like this house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You like him, don't you?  Your voice changes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think it does. (a beat) Anyway, he's indifferent to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think it's indifference. Kip comes bounding in with a fresh can.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hana was just telling me that you were indifferent -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey! - THE PATIENT #NAME?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'm indifferent to cooking, not Hana's cooking in particular. (stabbing at the tin with a bayonet) Have either of you ever tried condensed milk sandwiches? 125
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: .   MORNING. Caravaggio and the Patient are singing - an Arab song which they both know from Cairo days.  THUNDER accompanies them.  It's pouring. Suddenly the door is flung open and HANA, KIP and HARDY appear.  They have the stretcher with them. 127*.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: THE HEADLONG RUSH OF KIP, HARDLY

direction.raw_text: .    MORNING. A whoop precedes THE HEADLONG RUSH OF KIP, HARDLY and CARAVAGGIO as they cart the Patient across the Cloisters like manic stretcher- bearers.  Hana is with them, holding an umbrella over the Patient who bounces uncomfortably.  He is nervous, a little giddy.  The rain buckets down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Careful - careful! 127a*.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    MORNING. The storm tour includes a trip around the pond.  The Patient pushes away the umbrella, lets the rain drench him.   He grins at Hana.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is wonderful!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's he saying?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's saying it's wonderful! 128*.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .  DAY. Madox and Almasy are camped in one corner of THE LIBRARY, hunched over their maps and papers and journals and clashing furiously over the site of the next part of the expedition.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I'm telling you there's nothing there to explore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, because you can't see from the air! If you could explore from the air life would be very simple! (he yanks up a map) Look!  What is that?  Is that a wadi? That whole spur is a real possibility...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which we've overflown twice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which we couldn't explore because of rocks, because of cross-winds, it's sloppy. (stabbing another location) And here - and here - we could be staring at Zerzura. Other readers look over at this unseemly skirmish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So - on Thursday you don't trust Bell's map - Bell was a fool, Bell couldn't draw a map, but on Friday he's suddenly infallible? Almasy is surprised by Madox' anger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And where are the Expedition Maps?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In my room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Those maps belong to His Majesty's Government.  They're confidential. They shouldn't be left lying around for any Tom, Dick or Mary to have sight of.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the matter with you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be so bloody naive.  You know there's a war breaking out. (he tosses a slip of paper onto the map, recites its message) This arrived this morning.  By order of the British Government - all International Expeditions to be aborted by May 1939. 129
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: LIBRARY OF THE DEPARTMENT OF EGYPTOLOGY

direction.raw_text: .   DAY. Almasy and Madox walk down this busy and rather narrow street without pavements.  Both of them somber.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why do they care about our maps?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do we find in the desert?  Arrow heads, spears.  In a war, if you own the desert, you own North Africa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Own the desert. Almasy hesitates at a junction, clearly about to take leave of Madox.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That place at the base of a woman's throat?  You know - the hollow - here - does that have an official name? Madox looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For God's sake, man - pull yourself together. 130
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    CAIRO.    EVENING. The OPEN-AIR CINEMA is just beginning its evening programme. PATHE NEWS BEGINS and we date the event to April 1939.  Stories of imminent war jostle with images of Merrie England.  Village greens, sporting victories, Cruft's Dog Show.  Alone among the necking couples - mostly soldiers with their Egyptian girlfriends - in an otherwise empty block, is Katharine.  She's waiting for Almasy.  A SOLDIER comes over to Katharine's row and settles a couple of seats away from her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beggin your pardon, miss, but have you got a lighter? Katharine lights his cigarette and returns to the screen.  An item about Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers and TOP HAT.  The stars do their stuff.  The soldier moves a seat nearer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love Ginger, she's a foxy girl, ain't she?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fuck off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You heard me. The Soldier slinks off, muttering.  Katharine is wretched.  She sits head down, not watching the screen, marooned in her despair about duplicity, sordid assignations. Almasy arrives, slides in beside Katharine, his shadow momentarily large across the screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry. They watch the screen.  Katharine is weeping.  Almasy doesn't understand.  He puts his arm around her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't do this, I can't do this any more. 131*.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    CAIRO.    EVENING. A man walks round with A HAND BELL - announcing that the Park is closing.  He turns off the gaslights which illuminate the animal cages. Almasy and Katharine sit stiffly on a bench.  They don't speak.  Almasy puts his hands to his head, he rubs his shoulders.  The lights are gradually being extinguished around them. Finally, Katharine gets up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd better get back. (she keeps him away with a hand) Say goodbye here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not agreeing.  Don't think I'm agreeing, because I'm not. They stand, awkward.  Katharine rehearses her position.  The bell clangs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just know - any minute he'll find out, we'll barge into somebody we'll - and it will ill him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't go over it again, please. He takes her hands, lays his cheeks into them, then releases them, gets up, walks away.  She walks towards the gate.  He calls after her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katharine - He walks towards her, his smile awful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just wanted you to know. I'm not missing you yet. She nods, can't find this funny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You will.  You will. Then she turns sharply from him and catches her head against the gatepost, staggers at the shock of it, then hurries away. 132*.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    MORNING. Hana sits with the English Patient - the room shuttered against the morning light.  His breathing is noticeably worsening, a shudder of a breath, the shallow rise and fall of his chest perceptible.  Hana frets, touches his wrist, feeling for the pulse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm still here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'd better be.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't depend on it.  Will you? That little bit of air, each day there's less of it, which is al right, which is quite all right. She squeezes his hand, suddenly overwhelmed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been talking to Caravaggio - my research assistant - there's meant to be a ghost in the Cloisters.  I can join him! There's some kind of noise from the garden.  Muffled shouts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's the boy. Hana goes to the window, opens the shutters.  The day pours in. 132A*.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: HIS HANDS RAISED ABOVE HIM, HIS LEG HELD OUT STRANGELY

direction.raw_text: .    DAY. Hana sees Kip - barely visible - standing at the far perimeter of the garden in the olive groves, HIS HANDS RAISED ABOVE HIM, HIS LEG HELD OUT STRANGELY.  WIRES run from his foot in all directions as if he'd trodden in some elaborate steel cobweb. 133
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    DAY. Hana appears at the edge of the Olive groves and hurries towards Kip, who hasn't moved.  He shouts warning her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go to the left!  Keep to the left!  There are mines and trip wires everywhere! Hana stops, hoists up her skirt and circles left, tentative in the long grass.  He shouts, doesn't want her close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get Hardy.  He's on the other side of town.  In the hills.  Get him to hurry. She keeps coming, can see that he needs her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's okay - I'll help.  Please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The mines, the wires, there's a trick. Some explode if you stretch the wires, some if you cut them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do I do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a mine here, but the others are far enough away, I think at least to give me a chance.  I have to work out which one to cut before I fall over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So I follow the wires?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You get Hardy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I follow the wires. She kneels at his feet and tries to trace the tangled route of the web.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't touch them. She follows one wire back to the closest mine, and traces another back to Kip's foot.  Then she finds another one leading off to a second mine some thirty metres away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why would anyone do this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've done this.  I've had to do this. Then Hana's suddenly tense.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give me a second. She turns and tiptoes RIGHT THROUGH THE DANGER AREA, straight to what had seized her attention.  Kip is appalled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you doing?!  Hana! Heedless, she dodges another mine and its web of wires just as THE TORTOISE clambers onto a clump of rock, which is, in fact, ANOTHER CONCRETE-COVERED MINE. Hana snatches him up as he ambles towards the metal.  She turns, holding the protesting animal in triumph.  HER FOOT SNAGS ON A WIRE. She has to ease it off, in arabesque, still clutching the tortoise. She goes sideways to the safe zone - setting down the animal.  Then she's back with Kip.  He's seething.  She is strangely elated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is this business with you and explosives?  Do you think you're immune?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I promise you that was the right thing to do.  He's my good luck. (she gets the pliers from his belt, and hands them to him) Now cut.  This one. (she indicates the wire) I hope we don't die.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.  Get away from here.  Quick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not scared.  So many people have died around me.  But I would be a shame for us. (shrugs) I don't feel like being shy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must get away.  Before I cut.  I'm not cutting if you're here. He's struggling.  He's going to topple over if he cuts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Actually, you can't cut, can you? You'll fall over.  Give me the pliers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. But he hands them over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kiss me.  Before I cut.  Just in case.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't talk.  Check again.  Lie flat and then cut. Hana checks, lies down.  He bends as close to the ground as he dares AND KISSES HER, THEN SHE IMMEDIATELY CUTS. 134
direction.name: direction

result.heading: HER FOOT SNAGS ON A WIRE

direction.raw_text: .    CONTINUOUS. The Patient lies in bed.  He's agitated by the silence.  SUDDENLY THERE'S AN EXPLOSION.  He tries to shout, a croak which quickly reduces him to coughing and breathlessness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hana!  Hana!  Kip!  Hana! He tries to move.  He can't.  He's frantic. FOOTSTEPS, as someone hurtles up the stairs.  It's Hana.  She's ashamed to have forgotten him.  She rushes to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry.  I forgot you'd be worrying. We're all safe.  It was a mine, but not the mine.  Nobody's hurt.  I'm sorry. She calms him.  He's exhausted.  His eyes shine. 135
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    ITALY.    LATE DAY. Hana clings onto Kip as the TRIUMPH MOTORCYCLE hares along the circling road.  She has her arms around his waist.  His head turns to her for a second and she smiles. 136
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    TUSCANY.    DUSK. Kip and Hana have been detained at a ROAD BLOCK.  Kip is being questioned at a sentry post, his papers over-thoroughly inspected and accompanied by several meaningful glances at Hana, who waits, standing by the motorcycle.  One of the SOLDIERS saunters over and returns her papers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you're definitely traveling with him of your own free will?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just wanting to be sure.  And he's taking you to church?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.  We're going to a funeral.  A cow has died.  And in his religion they're sacred. The Soldier isn't sure what to make of this.  He signals to his companion who returns Kip's papers.  Kip walks back to the motorcycles. He says nothing.  He kicks the starter.  Hana gets on, slides her arms lovingly around him. 137
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    ITALY.    DUSK. IT'S GETTING DARK.  The bike, headlights on, crosses a bridge.  Kip has strapped on his crimson emergency light as they sail along the winding crest of mountain ridge that is a spine down Italy. 138
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   DUSK. Kip steers the motorbike into the deserted PIAZZA. They dismount and Kip starts to unbuckle his bulging satchel and unload the panniers.  Hana still doesn't know what's in store and looks questioningly at Kip as he walks up to the door of the CHURCH. 139
direction.name: direction

result.heading: THEN A FLARE SUDDENLY ILLUMINATES THE INTERIOR
PROTECTIVE SCAFFOLDING EVERYWHERE, AND SANDBAGS PILED UP HIGH AROUND THE ALTARS, AND THE STATUES

direction.raw_text: .    DUSK. They enter the Church.  It's in almost total darkness.  THEN A FLARE SUDDENLY ILLUMINATES THE INTERIOR.  It's magnificent.  Kip holds the flare, crimson on one arm, green pouring up from the other.  Hana walks behind him, still perplexed.  There is PROTECTIVE SCAFFOLDING EVERYWHERE, AND SANDBAGS PILED UP HIGH AROUND THE ALTARS, AND THE STATUES. A SECOND FLARE.  Kip has appeared through A SECRET DOOR high in the church, literally emerging from one of the frescoes which are momentarily visible.  He flings a rope over the rafters. Now Kip circles Hana with the rope, MAKING A SLING across her waist and shoulder.  He lights a smaller flair and hands it to her before disappearing. Hana stands holding the flare.  She can't see Kip, can only hear him scrambling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kip? He runs up the sandbags, right up into the rafters.  He collects the other end of the rope which is attached to Hana.  Holding onto it, he just STEPS OFF INTO THE DARKNESS. SIMULTANEOUSLY HANA IS SWUNG UP INTO THE AIR, her startled yelp echoing around the Church.  Kip touches ground, while Hana swings through space, coming to rest about three feet from the FRESCOED WALLS, painted by Piero Della Francesca.  Hana's flare makes a halo around her head. Now Kip, on the ground, still holding the rope, walks forward and causes Hana to SWING to the right.  She lets out a giddy laugh, exhilarated and nervous, and she flies, illuminating - en passant - faces, bodies, angels.  Kip guides the rope as if they were making love, which in a way they are. Hana arrives, hovering, in front of THE QUEEN OF SHEBA TALKING TO SOLOMON. She's overwhelmed.  She reaches out to touch the giant neck of the sad Queen. Kip slowly lets her down, paying out the length of the rope.  Hana's face is full of tears.  He smiles, holds her. 140
direction.name: direction

result.heading: HANA IS SWUNG UP INTO THE AIR,
THE QUEEN OF SHEBA TALKING TO SOLOMON

direction.raw_text: .    EVENING. Caravaggio is with the Patient.  He sits in the window.  Fiddles with the bandages of his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There was a general who wore a patch over a perfectly good eye.  The men fought harder for him.  Sometimes I think I could get up and dance. What's under your bandages? Caravaggio goes to him, holding out his hands, the bandage ends trailing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold the ends. The Patient holds them.  Caravaggio walks backwards, the bandages unraveling and unraveling. 141*.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .  BRITISH HEADQUARTERS.  JUNE 1942.  DAY. Caravaggio, thumbs intact and wearing a crumpled linen suit, walks through the mangled corridors of British HQ.  Smoke is rising from buildings, the ominous scream of Stuka dive-bombers in the distance as the harbor is pounded, the steady thud of explosions.  TOBRUK IS UNDER SIEGE.  BHQ is a place in the throws of dismantling itself. SECRETARIES are visiting braziers manned by ARAB BOYS who stoke the fires as boxes of papers are fed into them.  ASHES hover in the air. 142*.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    TOBRUK.    DAY. Caravaggio walks through a large room crowded with desks.  From one of them, a young woman, AICHA, kisses him, frowning at the chaos and the shelling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's waiting for you. Some doors are open, revealing men and women in uniform urgently SHREDDING DOCUMENTS.  Caravaggio knocks at an office whose door is ajar and where the incumbent, FENELON-BARNES, is stripping the room of his personal possessions-  photographs, stone branches, a cricket bat. 142a*.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   BHQ.   TOBRUK.   DAY. Caravaggio enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What a bloody flap, eh?  I heard from Alexandria this morning - apparently no-one there is accepting British pounds. And if you pick up a telephone everybody's practicing their German. (holds up some gramophone records) What do you do - do you take these things? (then, awkward) Look, Moose, we need you to stay in Tobruk.  A bit of a short straw but the thinking is we'll be back - I mean, we will be back - but...and in the interim we need eyes and ears on the ground. A BIG BOMB lands nearby.  The building shudders and plaster dust drops from the ceiling.  Almost oblivious, the two men head out of the office.  Fenelon-Barnes lugs the TRUNK last glimpsed in his tent by Almasy, until Caravaggio takes over. 143*.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TOBRUK. DAY. Fenelon-Barnes and Caravaggio make their way down the stairs and to the entrance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have 30, 000 troops in Tobruk. What are they going to be doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Giving Rommel a bloody nose. That's my suggestion.  But did you hear the BBC last nigh?  Tobruk is of no strategic importance - makes you wonder. AICHA is at the bottom of the stairs.  She falls into step.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jerry's got our maps you know.  Swines. Before the war we helped them run about the desert making maps - and now they get spies into Cairo using our maps, they'll get Rommel into Cairo using our maps. The whole of the desert like a bus route and we gave it to them.   Any foreigner who turned up - welcome to the Royal Geographic, take our maps.  Madox went mad, you know - you knew Peter Madox? - after he found out he'd been betrayed by his friend. Absolutely destroyed the poor sod.  Shot himself in a church in Dorset. Caravaggio opens the door, Fenelon-Barnes goes through. 144*.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    TOBRUK.    DAY. The Fenelon-Barnes trunk is taken from Caravaggio and joins the pile of luggage and artifacts, which wait to be shipped out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like to get that bastard Almasy - settle the score, eh?  That's my fantasy - said he, clearing out. Must have been a spy all along. 145
direction.name: direction

result.heading: IN A LINE, WEARING HIS SHABBY SUIT, IS CARAVAGGIO
AS HE TURNS BRIEFLY AND HELPLESSLY OUT OF CONCERN FOR HER

result.ToD: THEIR EYES CATCH FOR AN INSTANT AND THE OFFICER SEES IT
result.heading: THEIR EYES CATCH FOR AN INSTANT AND THE OFFICER SEES IT

direction.raw_text: .    DAY. A GERMAN TROOP CARRIER rumbles forward passing a line of BEDRAGGLED BRITISH POWS as they're marched along the side of harbor. 146a*. EXT.    TOBRUK RUINED QUARTER.    DAY. A HILL OF SALVAGED ARMY BOOTS is being explored by a couple of GERMAN SOLDIERS in search of better footwear.  Below them the POWS trudge by, one of them barefoot.  ONE OF THE GERMANS tosses down a pair of boots then continues his own perusal. 146b*. EXT.    TOBRUK SQUARE.    DAY. A crowd of Tobruk CIVILIANS - French and Italians among the MOSTLY ARAB FACES.  Their papers are being thoroughly checked by officers sitting at open desks. IN A LINE, WEARING HIS SHABBY SUIT, IS CARAVAGGIO.  AN ARAB WOMAN in front of him is arguing over the identity of her ominously CAUCASIAN-LOOKING CHILD.  An INTERPRETER mediates.  The OFFICER doesn't believe the woman.  She's getting frantic at the possibility of losing her child. Suddenly there's a disturbance as a WOMAN is dragged along the line by her hair.  She's bloodied, and has been tortured, and it's hard to recognize her as the pretty AICHA.  She touches a couple of people in the line.  They're horrified.  Soldiers pull them away.  Caravaggio doesn't look, stares straight ahead.  An officer watches him AS HE TURNS BRIEFLY AND HELPLESSLY OUT OF CONCERN FOR HER.  THEIR EYES CATCH FOR AN INSTANT AND THE OFFICER SEES IT. CARAVAGGIO RUNS, bolts for cover, vaulting the rubble which blocks one corner of the square.  The CONGREGATION throws itself to the ground until the square has only standing soldiers and a running man. 146c*. EXT.   TOBRUK.   INTERIOR OF RUINED BUILDING.   DAY. Shots pursue Caravaggio as he disappears behind the rubble, then bobs up again as he darts inside a blasted building.  He clambers up some ruined stairs, heaves over the wall. 146d*. EXT.   TOBRUK.   FACADE OF RUINED BUILDING.   DAY. CARAVAGGIO grabs a metal bar on the facade of the building, from which he hangs, looking for the next foothold.  Soldiers appear along the top of the building, shouting, rifles ready.  AN OFFICER arrives and stops the soldiers firing, and the others begin to laugh as Caravaggio hangs from the bar fifteen feet above a balcony, slowly losing his strength. Another SOLDIER waits for him in the balcony below.  Now he starts to laugh.  Caravaggio hangs. 147*.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: HIS HANDS MANACLED TO ITS THICK WOODEN LEGS

direction.raw_text: . TOBRUK. NOVEMBER 13,1942. DAY. Caravaggio is slumped at a table, HIS HANDS MANACLED TO ITS THICK WOODEN LEGS.  There's A TELEPHONE at another table in the corner of the room attended by a CLERK with A STENOGRAPHER working next to him.  The room has stone walls which appear damp, and no windows.  SOLDIERS stand guard at the door.  It's a horrible room.  Caravaggio is trying to sleep, he's unshaven, and pasty-looking.  His interrogator, Muller, seems incredibly tired and aggravated.  He's on the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, yes, yes, yes, yes. He slams down the phone and comes back to the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: David Caravaggio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Petty thief, six months imprisonment Kingston Penitentiary, 1937.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I keep explaining.  You've got the wrong man.  My name is Bellini - Antonio Bellini.  Bellini, Caravaggio, both painters, I think that is confusing you. Muller doesn't even pay attention, he's going through a file.  Pulls out some photographs, starts spreading them out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is you.  This was taken in Cairo at British Headquarters - July 41.  And so was this - August 41.  And this -February 42.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's impossible.  I was buying or selling something.  I've been to Cairo many times.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are a Canadian spy working for the Allies.  Code-name Moose. THE PHONE rings again, is answered.  The Clerk calls to Muller who gets up, irritably.  Caravaggio addresses the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Could I have a doctor?  I am passing blood.  I must be bleeding internally. (to the clerk) Can you get a doctor?  Look - (he spits onto the table, there's blood in his mouth) I'm leaking blood. (he indicates a Guard) He kicks me.  He kicks me all the time. Nobody responds.  Muller is irascible on the phone, checking his watch, negotiating time.  The call finishes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's asking for a doctor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want a doctor?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I've been asking for weeks, a month, I don't know, also my leg was -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We don't have a doctor, but we do have a nurse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A nurse?  Well, sure, a nurse is great. A nurse?  Great. Muller nods at the Clerk, who instantly gets up.  Just then the telephone rings again.  He hesitates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leave it and get the nurse! The Clerk exits.  The phone rings.  The Stenographer is plagued by flies.  Suddenly he slaps at one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why is there so much nose?  I can't hear myself think! (turns to Caravaggio) Look - give me something.  So we can all get out of this room.  A name.  A code. (wiping his face) It's too hot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I slept with the girl.  I've got a wife in Tripoli.  A girl comes up and points at you, you only see trouble. The NURSE comes in.  She is Arab and her head is covered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll tell you what I'm going to do.  This is your nurse, by the way.  She's Moslem, so she'll understand all of this.  What's the punishment for adultery?  Let's leave it at that.  You're married and you were fucking another woman, so that's - is it the hands that are cut off? Or is that for stealing?  Does anyone know? There's silence.  Muller turns to Caravaggio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you must know.  You were brought up Libya, yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't cut me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or was it Toronto?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't cut me.  Come on. Now the phone starts again.  The CLERK picks it up, there's a terse exchange, he puts the receiver on the desk, waits for the moment to interrupt Muller.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ten fingers.  How about this?  You give me a name for every finger - doesn't matter who.  I get something, you keep something.  I'm trying to be reasonable.  Fenelon-Barnes, we could call that two names. (pauses, suddenly puzzled) Are thumbs fingers? (in GERMAN to the others) Is a thumb a finger? No response.  Muller opens his palms to Caravaggio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I get no help from these people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The telephone - Muller walks over, takes the receiver and slams it down.  an AIR RAID SIREN is going off somewhere, and now the faint sound of explosions is also discernible, but all muffled in this room with the steady clack- clack of the STENOGRAPHER.  At that moment, Muller suddenly becomes aware of what is happening.  He turns on the Stenographer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That Geneva Convention.  I'm - Muller peremptorily rips out the paper, throws it on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't do that!  Hey - come on! DURING THIS Muller's gone to the table, pulled out a drawer and produced A CUT-THROAT RAZOR.  He hands it to the nurse, makes a line across his own left thumb and jerks his head towards Caravaggio.  The nurse is extremely reluctant.  Muller claps his hands, pushes her towards Caravaggio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go!  Hey!  Go! Caravaggio is in terror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh Jesus.  Oh Jesus Christ. The guards come away from the door and press down on Caravaggio's shoulders to prevent him from moving.  The nurse, grim-faced, approaches, kneels at the table. CARAVAGGIO (as she prepares to cut) Listen, I'll give you a name.  What name did you say?  I knew them! I promise.  Please - please! And then he SCREAMS AND SCREAMS and jerks up, carrying the guards and the table with him, all heaving off the ground, the nurse thrown off balance.  He falls to the floor, ROARING WITH PAIN, blood everywhere, the table on top of him.  The AIR RAID is continuing outside, the PHONE IS RINGING, the nurse stands, pale, blood all over her uniform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cut the other thumb. He stabs at his own right thumb.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This one!  Come on! The nurse, horrified, shakes her head.  Muller snatches the razor from her and heads towards the prostate Caravaggio. One Guard has got to his feet and grips Caravaggio around the neck in half-nelson, others holding his legs, while Muller approaches. Caravaggio can't move.  He's gurgling as the Guard almost strangles him.  His eyes are streaming with tears. Now Muller is at his other hand, and the ROAR of pain again lifts Caravaggio to his feet, THE WHOLE TABLE RISING IN THE AIR, his mutilated hands slipping from the handcuffs lie Houdini, the drawers of the table SPILLING their contents everywhere, before he sinks to his knees like a gored bull and BLACKS OUT. 148
direction.name: direction

result.heading: THE WHOLE TABLE RISING IN THE AIR,

direction.raw_text: .    TOBRUK.    DAY. LATER, and Caravaggio comes round.  His eyes open and then his face spasms with pain.  He looks down at his ruined hands, then realizes he's alone on the floor of the room, the papers still scattered, the table on its side.  He gets up and staggers out of the open door and up the stairs. 149*.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .  TOBRUK.   DAY. The corridor is deserted, but the body of a GERMAN SOLDIER sprawls on the stairs leading up to daylight.  Outside Caravaggio can hear fighting. 150*.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: A PARACHUTE FLOATS DOWN BY HIM
A PARATROOPER LANDS ON THE ROOF, AND GESTURES TO CARAVAGGIO TO RAISE HIS HANDS

direction.raw_text: .    INTERROGATION BUILDING.    DAY. Caravaggio walks unsteadily along the roof of the building.  Grey and yellow gusts of smoke and the rat-ta-tat-tat of machine gun fire accompany him, and there's the sound of vehicles screeching and people shouting nearby, but no visual clues as to what's happening. SUDDENLY A PARACHUTE FLOATS DOWN BY HIM.  THEN ANOTHER.  THEN ANOTHER. HE'S SURROUNDED BY PARACHUTES.  THE BRITISH ARE RECLAIMING TOBRUK.  A PARATROOPER LANDS ON THE ROOF, AND GESTURES TO CARAVAGGIO TO RAISE HIS HANDS.  HE SLOWLY DOES SO. 151*.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    NIGHT. Caravaggio stands in front of the bed, holding up his NAKED HANDS to the Patient, like a man surrendering - two flaps like gills where his thumbs were.  The Patient reaches out to take his hands and gently lowers them.  Caravaggio finds his bandages, start to wrap them back round his fists.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The man who took my thumbs, I found him eventually - he's dead.  The man who took my photograph, I found him too - that took me a year.  He's dead.  Another man took that man across the desert to Cairo.  Now I intend to find him. The LIGHTS FROM THE MOTORBIKE approaching the Monastery, its growl. Caravaggio goes to the window and watches as Kip and Hana arrive. 152
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   CAIRO, 1939.   NIGHT. Last seen at the Troops Christmas party, the INNER COURTYARD has been transformed into an elegant outdoor banquet, with band. The Almasy/Madox team is assembled for A FAREWELL DINNER.  They are waiting for Almasy to arrive, his seat conspicuously empty.  He is very late. And then he's there, dangerous drunk, terribly dashing.  He practically dances to his chair, which he drags violently away from its position opposite Katharine.  He bows to Lady Hampton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I believe I'm rather late.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good, we're all here?  A toast, to the International Sand club - may it soon resurface.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The International Sand Club!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Misfits, buggers, fascists, and paedophiles.  God bless us every one. The others drink, trying to ignore his mood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oops!  Mustn't say International. Dirty word.  Filthy word.  His Majesty! Die Fuhrer!  Il Duce.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry, what's your point?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the people here don't want us. Are you kidding?  The Egyptians are desperate to get rid of the Colonials... (to an embarrassed Fouad) - isn't that right?  Their best people get down on hands and knees begging to be spared a knighthood. (to his host, Sir Hampton) Isn't that right? Ronnie Hampton shrugs.  They're all very uncomfortable.  Almasy glares at Clifton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's my point? (standing up) Oh!  I've invented a new dance - the Bosphorus Hug.  Anybody up to it? Madox?  D'Ag?  Come on D'Aggers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's eat first.  Sit down. The Band is now playing Manhattan - Almasy, without missing a beat, begins to sing, replacing the words with alternatives he knows.  He lurches around.  Katharine can't look at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...We'll bathe at Brighton, the fish we'll frighten when we're in.  your bathing suit so thin will make the shellfish grin, fin to fin. --  Those were the words - actually - before they were cleaned up.  Could be a song for you, Mrs. Clifton - (a perfect English accent) #NAME? Madox gets up and pulls Almasy into his chair, taking charge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, either shut up, or go home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Absolutely right, shut up.  Lashings of apologies all round. 153*.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: MOST OF THE GROUP ARE DANCING

direction.raw_text: .    NIGHT. Later, now MOST OF THE GROUP ARE DANCING.  We see Katharine dancing with Rupert Douglas, enjoying herself.  Bermann is there and even Madox jogging and grinning foolishly.  Clifton looks at Katharine who, as the dance ends, excuses herself to go to the cloakroom.  Almasy hovers in the shadows, unseen. 154*.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    NIGHT. Katharine comes along the familiar warren of rooms and corridors and is suddenly confronted by Almasy, tortured and out of control.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why did you hold his collar?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?  What?  That boy, that little boy, you were holding his collar, gripping his collar, what for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you let me pass?
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't do this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've watched you - on verandahs, at Garden Parties, at the Races - how can you stand there?  How can you ever smile?  As if your life hadn't capsized?
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dance with me.
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    NIGHT. Hana sits with the Patient.  His eyes are full of tears.  He opens them, sees her, watching over him.  He's embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you go? (wiping his eyes) You should sleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you like me to? He nods.  She gets up, touches his hand, then leaves. 156*.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .    NIGHT. Hana leaves the room, then turns and sees A TINY LAMP on the floor, it's made from a SNAIL SHELL and oil.  She bends to it curiously, then sees a second lamp half-way down the stairs, then a third further down. She smiles in the light, then follows the trail. 157
